Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 04:40PM wenweb wrote: Lets face it, it's human nature...misery loves company and there is no two ways about it, no matter what anyone says.  Not one of us was supposed to get cancer, but we did.  I agree with CK55.  I have been doing EVERYTHING right and I still got BC.  I am tired of reading/hearing " do or don't do this to prevent BC.  There was nothing else I could have done not to get BC.  It's kind of tough in that situation not to be curious why it was you and not someone else.  I know this sounds cruel, but I like caaclark am a very nice person, it's just been a tough year :=)
Posts.Title: This makes me feel terrible...anyone else? shockedat39 chrishat

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2013 02:53PM wenweb wrote: Hi.  I know that I don't belong on this thread (sorry), but wanted to impart some info.  While taking Tamoxifen I got hemorrhoids.  I had never had one in my entire life (I'm 58), not even while I was pregnant.  About a month after I stopped taking the Tamoxifen, they went away and have not returned.  I have no doubt the T was the cause.  This makes me believe that medications can cause ANY symptoms/side effects regardless of whether of not your Dr. has heard of it.
Posts.Title: Vaginal/Rectal tears.....Arimidex?? meima-Bev SophieJean

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 07:11AM wenweb wrote: Hi Claire,  My story is a little different than your's, but is has also made me wonder whether I have had radiation damage.  I'm 3 years out!!  I have been going through a tough time with uncontrolled asthma since May.  I have had 2 CT scans, 2 chest x-rays, been on some rounds of prednisone. Everything always checks out fine. Everytime I go to the pulmonologist, my O2 is 99 and my lungs always sound clear.  I end up thinking that the docs think I'm crazy!!  The pulmonologist says I am a mystery to him, and he is ready to send me to a cardiologist to see if I have any heart issues.  My gut is telling me that I don't, because I am like you and live an active life style (running, walking, yoga, back packing) with no difficulties.  I have had asthma for 30 years and never had any difficulties that have lasted this long.
Posts.Title: Radiation induced bronchitis? claireinaz wenweb

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2012 12:59PM wenweb wrote: Hi amandamarie,  Yes, I believe it is very common.  I was quite sore for many months after my surgery, both in the node area as well as where the actual growth was removed.  When I thought it was starting to feel better, I would get caught off guard when carrying groceries or something that I would gather up and lean aginst my chest.  I asked my BS about this, and he said that it might be sore forever. It is much less so now (as you can see I have just passed the 3 year mark :), but I still get caught, again when carrying groceries and in the node area particulary when I am doing yoga and am in a position where my arms are overhead in a stretch.  I can now comfortably lean on the area when sleeping, it did take a long time though. Sorry to the be bearer of not such good news.  Hope this helped.
Posts.Title: im still haveing pain where my lymphnodes were removed amandamarie Jennie93

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2012 05:32AM wenweb wrote: Hi There,  I didn't have chemo, so it's not really my place on this thread, but couldn't resist adding my thoughts.  I have lived in someone else's home for an extended period.  Krissy, in addition to all of the great answers you received, consider how you might feel if you do well with the chemo and are able to continue with all or most of your daily activities and rountines.  If you are staying with someone (family or friend), you won't be in your own house, your own bed, or have access to the little things we can always find to do in your own home.  Things like "oh, I've been meaning to get to this or that", cleaning out a drawer, closet etc, small but dooable things even if you are feeling kind of blah.  I've found that staying with someone leaves me essentially with nothing to do other than feeling fidigetty and wishing I was in my own home. If you do not feel well, you could go to the Hawaii plan, but have your friends and family come to your area for 2 weeks each in order to help you out.  The Dr. component is a large part of your care as mentioned.  Also, would your insuance cover your care if you temporally moved to another area? More food for thought :)  Best wishes
Posts.Title: Relocation for treatment??? Krissy5 wenweb

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 06:17PM wenweb wrote: This is not intended to discourage anyone, but rather the truth of the matter.  My lumpectomy was 2 years ago, and that area is still tender (to pressure like a big hug etc).  The area under my arm where the nodes were removed feels "tight" when I stretch (which I do often at yoga).  My BS said that it could likely feel that way forever.  This of course is not like the discomfort after surgery, but I was expecting things to "go back to feeling normal".  Not :>(  Best wishes to all of you. Wendy

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2012 06:20AM wenweb wrote: Crystal Thanks for the update.  I know that you have already figured this out...cataracts are no big deal.  EVERYONE gets cataracts-if they live long enough-not to be a downer.  It's a natural progression of the aging process, and easily fixed.  No worries-right? Good for you saying no to an antidepressant.  Too often I think they are over used and an individual may not have the wherewithall to wonder if they are truly depressed if there Dr suggests it.  I am not saying that they do not have a purpose, as surely they help millions of people.  Clearly from your posts, you are having anxiety at this point, not depression.  I'll be thinking of you on Thursday.

Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2018 09:14PM - edited Oct 29, 2018 12:05AM by wenweb Hi everyone, I haven't been on the site for a while. I recently celebrated 9 years cancer free at the beginning of September, just before my annual mammogram, I began to have pain on (what seemed to be) a rib on the right side, same side as my original IDC stage 1 in 2009. I reported it when I checked in for my mammogram, and they changed the billing code to a diagnostic mammogram rather than a routine yearly screening. The mammogram was normal, but I was told I should have an MRI under the circumstances. The MRI was also normal. I saw my oncologist today who ordered a bone scan, after determining for certain that the pain was on a rib, not my breast. I asked her if I should be worried, and she said "maybe a little". I asked her if she knew the chance of recurrence for those who were stage 1 with negative nodes. Right off the bat, she said 2%, and laughed because she said she only knew because she is currently writing a paper... After that, she spoke openly and honestly with me about what if it turns out that I have bone mets. She said there is a specific type of bone met with BC, which involves only one location, and even though you are considered stage 4 at that point, that it is completely curable. Of course if there are more spots, thats a different story...I haven't shared any of this with anyone. I have been divorced for just over 4 years, and don't want to concern anyone in my family prematurely. I am concerned, not overly worried, but that's why I'm here...Anyone with a similar story or situation?
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2013 06:32PM wenweb wrote: It's normal to be fearful.  You took the step of calling your doc, and they did not follow through, which doesn't mean you should not.  Be it good or be it bad, you need to find out.  For me there is always some relief in turing things over to the doctor-it helps to tone down all of the "what if's".  Only a small fraction of lumps turn out to be cancerous-keep that in mind when you call your doc back tomorrow :)  Good-luck!!  Keep us posted!!

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2012 03:12PM - edited Dec 23, 2012 06:05PM by wenweb Hi runner,  I know it's holiday time and that could put in glitch in timely results.  It's been my experience (from having had more than one biopsy) that bad news travels faster than good news.  I think you are being realistic as opposed to pessimistic in terms of preparing yourself.  The fact is that your lump already is what it is (or isn't) already.  Try and keep your mind occupied the best you can, and enjoy what the following days may bring your way.   Best Wishes

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2014 12:39PM wenweb wrote: Hi There,  If able, I would continue training and see how it goes, you can always drop out closer to the date if need be.  I had more restrictions after my biopsy than the lumpectomy when  I was told by my BS that I could do anything I wanted to.  Really?  He probably knew that there were certain things I wouldn't want to do--such as running (he is a runner too).  It's been over 4 years now, and I think it was probably about a month before I started running again.  Obviously, it's different for everyone, and I'm small breasted.  Have you thought of (or do you ever) wearing 2 sport bras?   Good-luck!!
Posts.Title: Training for a marathon - after a lump removal - advice please MrsBrightside Runmamaof4

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2010 10:16PM wenweb wrote: I have not had chemo, but like DMS, have been using Vagifem since menopause 6 years ago.  I stopped briefly after my DX, but like ck55 started getting regular UTI's (the first one I got started the  night before my lumpectomy and I was so afraid that the surgery would be cancelled I took 2 grams of Cipro and didn't tell anyone).  Also as ck55 states, the vaginal tissues have to "plump" up, so Shanagirl, if you give the Vagifem a chance, hopefully you will see some results.  Sex isn't as comfortable as it once was, but it's a heck of a lot better and no more UTI's.  There is so much controversy about whether it's okay to use vaginal estrogen with BC, but for some of us it is about quality of life when dealing with everything else that goes along with a BC DX. Medigal- sorry for everything you have had to suffer through.  As if the big C isn't bad enough...
Posts.Title: Chemo Brain Ok, but chemo vagina? Help!!!! Shanagirl BlondiShanagirl

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2010 05:36PM wenweb wrote: FYI...may not work for everyone...once I got stable (using every day for 2 weeks and then twice weekly thereafter), I began to use it once per week.  That seems to hold me most of the time.  Maybe once every 6-8 weeks I will use it twice per week.  It is a quality of life issue and using vaginal estrogen with BC is not to be taken lightly.   Hope this helps someone.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2010 02:41PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:51AM by wenweb Chrissyc, Mets are when the cancer spreads to other body part other than the place of origin=metastastize.  It takes a while to get the lingo down.   I also think that stress can cause cancer.  When I found out that after menopause when the ovaries no longer make estrogen, and that among 2 other places it is still made in the adrenal glands, this struck a chord with me. In addition to being a worrier, I had had a very stressful year+ prior to my diagnosis.  Best wishes.  Wendy
